values.title: Jenkins should compile tests even if it doesn't run them

content.raw:
In pull request #1501, there was a compilation error in `MainWindow_TEST.cc`, which was not caught by Jenkins, since it doesn't compile that test. I think Jenkins should compile all tests to catch these types of errors, though it should not run all the tests if we expect them to fail.

@\_jrivero_

In pull request #1501, there was a compilation error in MainWindow_TEST.cc, which was not caught by Jenkins, since it doesn't compile that test. I think Jenkins should compile all tests to catch these types of errors, though it should not run all the tests if we expect them to fail.

@_jrivero_

values.title: RTS tool does not rotate model dynamics

content.raw:
example: 

1. Roll the vehicle down a ramp

1. pause the simulation 

1. rotate the vehicle 90 degrees

1. Run the simulation again

Currently the vehicle tips over on its side in the direction where it was previously heading instead of moving towards the new direction it is now facing. 

Question: Should this be the expected outcome or should we support rotating the physics state of the model too?
content.html:
example:

  1. Roll the vehicle down a ramp

  2. pause the simulation

  3. rotate the vehicle 90 degrees

  4. Run the simulation again

Currently the vehicle tips over on its side in the direction where it was previously heading instead of moving towards the new direction it is now facing.

Question: Should this be the expected outcome or should we support rotating the physics state of the model too?

values.title: J_orig not correct inside ODE quickstep PGS_LCP solver

content.raw:
The `J_orig` is allocated [here](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/25f2e961e70803d36301ac22667492cbcc2def25/deps/opende/src/quickstep.cpp?at=default#cl-261), to keep a clean copy of `J`, but we didn't copy the values in `J` to `J_orig` after we create `J`

The `J_orig` is passed to call the `PGS_LCP` [here](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/25f2e961e70803d36301ac22667492cbcc2def25/deps/opende/src/quickstep.cpp?at=default#cl-485), with wrong values. 

Inside `PGS_LCP` function, `J_orig` is used [here](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/25f2e961e70803d36301ac22667492cbcc2def25/deps/opende/src/quickstep_pgs_lcp.cpp?at=default#cl-391), which is inside the preconditioning computation, of which `precon_iteration = 0`, so it doesn't affect the performance. 


Once preconditioning is enabled, there would be an issue. I will make a pull request on this
content.html:
The J_orig is allocated here, to keep a clean copy of J, but we didn't copy the values in J to J_orig after we create J

The J_orig is passed to call the PGS_LCP here, with wrong values.

Inside PGS_LCP function, J_orig is used here, which is inside the preconditioning computation, of which precon_iteration = 0, so it doesn't affect the performance.

Once preconditioning is enabled, there would be an issue. I will make a pull request on this

values.title: physics classes call sensors functions

content.html:
The libgazebo_sensors library links with libgazebo_physics but not the other way around. This allows the sensor library to call physics functions. However, the physics library also calls sensor functions. Is this a circular linking problem?

$ grep -rnI sensors:: gazebo/physics/
gazebo/physics/Model.cc:676:        !sensors::SensorManager::Instance()->SensorsInitialized() &&
gazebo/physics/Link.cc:158:          sensors::create_sensor(sensorElem, this->GetWorld()->GetName(),
gazebo/physics/Link.cc:259:    sensors::remove_sensor(*iter);
gazebo/physics/Link.cc:779:    sensors::SensorPtr sensor = sensors::get_sensor(*iter);
gazebo/physics/Joint.cc:81:    sensors::remove_sensor(*iter);
gazebo/physics/Joint.cc:267:          sensors::create_sensor(sensorElem, this->GetWorld()->GetName(),
gazebo/physics/Joint.cc:340:    sensors::remove_sensor(*iter);
gazebo/physics/Joint.cc:574:    sensors::SensorPtr sensor = sensors::get_sensor(*iter);
gazebo/physics/Link.hh:377:      /// sensors::Sensor. Access to a Sensor object
gazebo/physics/Link.hh:378:      /// is accomplished through the sensors::SensorManager. This was done to
gazebo/physics/World.cc:557:      sensors::SensorManager::Instance()->SensorsInitialized())
gazebo/physics/World.cc:990:  sensors::SensorManager::Instance()->ResetLastUpdateTimes();

values.title: Model Editor: Copy mesh and material files

content.raw:
If a model which includes other files like meshes, material textures and scripts is saved, the saved SDF will reference the original location of these files.

Probably the files should be copied into the new folder to be consistent with the gazebo model database structure.

It would also be nice to keep the original config file for loaded models.
content.html:
If a model which includes other files like meshes, material textures and scripts is saved, the saved SDF will reference the original location of these files.

Probably the files should be copied into the new folder to be consistent with the gazebo model database structure.

It would also be nice to keep the original config file for loaded models.

values.title: Selection behavior shared by multiple gzclients

content.raw: When two gzclients and one gzserver are running, selections in one gzclient will be mirrored in the other. This is because selections published by `GLWidget` also get received by `GLWidget` and fire off the callback `OnSelectionMsg`.
content.html: When two gzclients and one gzserver are running, selections in one gzclient will be mirrored in the other. This is because selections published by GLWidget also get received by GLWidget and fire off the callback OnSelectionMsg.

values.title: Alternative approach to including ign-math (formerly pull request #1535)

content.raw:
pull request #1534 presents one approach to integrating the [ignition-math](https://bitbucket.org/ignitionrobotics/ign-math) library into gazebo as an eventual replacement for the `gazebo::math` classes. This pull request presents another approach.

Switching to `ignition-math` will require changes to both gazebo code and downstream gazebo plugin code. It's my understanding that the philosophy of pull request #1534 is to encourage everyone to stop using `gazebo/math/*.hh` header files, `gazebo::math::` classes and helper functions, and start using `ignition-math` instead. This will also require adapting to some API differences between `ignition-math` and `gazebo::math`.

This will be a lot of work/pain. It would be one thing if it was only pain for us, but it will also affect our downstream users who write gazebo plugins using math classes, which is likely almost 100% since math is our lowest-level library. It would actually be even worse for our users, who would need to use `#ifdef`'s if they want their plugin to support multiple versions of gazebo. I have an alternative in this pull request that could reduce the pain of transition for ourselves and our users.

Caveat: I haven't fully implemented it; so it might not work, but I think it's worth discussing. I'm willing to support the approach in pull request #1534, but I'd like this approach to at least be considered.

Approach, focusing only on the `math::Angle` class as an example (see Step 4 for the key idea):

1. Add `ignition-math` as an optional dependency (6df6b70); it will later be required

2. Deprecate `gazebo::math::Angle` functions that don't match the `ignition::math::Angle` API and add replacement functions that do match (9d1c07f)

3. Fix `gazebo::math::Angle` deprecation warnings in gazebo (0558a69)

4. If `ignition-math` is found, typedef `ignition::math::Angle` as `gazebo::math::Angle` and don't compile Angle.cc; this is the key part that could reduce the pain of transition. Users would still be able to include `gazebo/math/Angle.hh` and use `gazebo::math::Angle`, but it would all simply point to `ignition/math/Angle.hh` and `ignition::math::Angle`.

5. Eventually make `ignition-math` required and delete all the `.cc` files in `gazebo/math`.

Other caveats:

1. I had to remove `class Angle` from `gazebo/math/MathTypes.hh` (a6c6ada) because it was causing problems. I'm not sure if this is a big deal or not or if it will be for other math classes.

2. I saw a conflict between something in `gazebo/math/Helpers.hh` and `ignition/math/Helpers.hh`, though I can't remember where I saw it. Hopefully jenkins shows it.
content.html:
pull request #1534 presents one approach to integrating the ignition-math library into gazebo as an eventual replacement for the gazebo::math classes. This pull request presents another approach.

Switching to ignition-math will require changes to both gazebo code and downstream gazebo plugin code. It's my understanding that the philosophy of pull request #1534 is to encourage everyone to stop using gazebo/math/*.hh header files, gazebo::math:: classes and helper functions, and start using ignition-math instead. This will also require adapting to some API differences between ignition-math and gazebo::math.

This will be a lot of work/pain. It would be one thing if it was only pain for us, but it will also affect our downstream users who write gazebo plugins using math classes, which is likely almost 100% since math is our lowest-level library. It would actually be even worse for our users, who would need to use #ifdef's if they want their plugin to support multiple versions of gazebo. I have an alternative in this pull request that could reduce the pain of transition for ourselves and our users.

Caveat: I haven't fully implemented it; so it might not work, but I think it's worth discussing. I'm willing to support the approach in pull request #1534, but I'd like this approach to at least be considered.

Approach, focusing only on the math::Angle class as an example (see Step 4 for the key idea):

  1. Add ignition-math as an optional dependency (6df6b70); it will later be required

  2. Deprecate gazebo::math::Angle functions that don't match the ignition::math::Angle API and add replacement functions that do match (9d1c07f)

  3. Fix gazebo::math::Angle deprecation warnings in gazebo (0558a69)

  4. If ignition-math is found, typedef ignition::math::Angle as gazebo::math::Angle and don't compile Angle.cc; this is the key part that could reduce the pain of transition. Users would still be able to include gazebo/math/Angle.hh and use gazebo::math::Angle, but it would all simply point to ignition/math/Angle.hh and ignition::math::Angle.

  5. Eventually make ignition-math required and delete all the .cc files in gazebo/math.

Other caveats:

  1. I had to remove class Angle from gazebo/math/MathTypes.hh (a6c6ada) because it was causing problems. I'm not sure if this is a big deal or not or if it will be for other math classes.

  2. I saw a conflict between something in gazebo/math/Helpers.hh and ignition/math/Helpers.hh, though I can't remember where I saw it. Hopefully jenkins shows it.

values.title: Button to step the world is enabled at the wrong times

content.raw:
`gazebo5` has what I believe to be the correct behaviour:

1. Start a simulation in unpaused state, the pause button shows and the step button is **disabled**.

2. Pause the simulation: the pause button becomes play and the step button becomes **enabled**.

But on `default`, this happens:

1. Start a simulation in unpaused state, the pause button shows and the step button is **enabled**.

2. Pause the simulation: the pause button becomes play and the step button becomes **disabled**.
content.html:
gazebo5 has what I believe to be the correct behaviour:

  1. Start a simulation in unpaused state, the pause button shows and the step button is disabled.

  2. Pause the simulation: the pause button becomes play and the step button becomes enabled.

But on default, this happens:

  1. Start a simulation in unpaused state, the pause button shows and the step button is enabled.

  2. Pause the simulation: the pause button becomes play and the step button becomes disabled.

values.title: gzserver --help should return 0

content.raw:
Currently `gzserver --help` does not return 0:

~~~
$ gzserver --help && echo this message should be echoed
gzserver -- Run the Gazebo server.

`gzserver` [options] <world_file>

Gazebo server runs simulation and handles commandline options, starts a Master, runs World update and sensor generation loops.

Options:
  -v [ --version ]              Output version information.
  --verbose                     Increase the messages written to the terminal.
  -h [ --help ]                 Produce this help message.
  -u [ --pause ]                Start the server in a paused state.
  -e [ --physics ] arg          Specify a physics engine 
                                (ode|bullet|dart|simbody).
  -p [ --play ] arg             Play a log file.
  -r [ --record ]               Record state data.
  --record_encoding arg (=zlib) Compression encoding format for log data 
                                (zlib|bz2|txt).
  --record_path arg             Absolute path in which to store state data
  --seed arg                    Start with a given random number seed.
  --iters arg                   Number of iterations to simulate.
  --minimal_comms               Reduce the TCP/IP traffic output by gzserver
  -s [ --server-plugin ] arg    Load a plugin.

~~~

This happens because [Server::ParseArgs](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/4dc9b5b7ef3049f4fa7c86a99a22bf579a6cbd72/gazebo/Server.cc#cl-78) returns `bool`. [server_main.cc](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/4dc9b5b7ef3049f4fa7c86a99a22bf579a6cbd72/gazebo/server_main.cc#cl-37) uses the return value of `Server::ParseArgs` to determine if a server should be started.

Instead, I think `Server::ParseArgs` could return `int`, with a positive value indicating that a server should be started, and otherwise just pass along the returned value:

~~~
diff -r 4dc9b5b7ef30 gazebo/server_main.cc
--- a/gazebo/server_main.cc	Fri Mar 20 17:48:04 2015 -0700
+++ b/gazebo/server_main.cc	Mon Mar 23 17:53:15 2015 -0700
@@ -34,8 +34,11 @@
     gazebo::util::LogRecord::Instance()->Init("gzserver");
 
     server = new gazebo::Server();
-    if (!server->ParseArgs(argc, argv))
-      return -1;
+    {
+      int parse = server->ParseArgs(argc, argv);
+      if (parse <= 0)
+        return parse;
+    }
 
     server->Run();
     server->Fini();
~~~

Then the return codes in ParseArgs should be changed accordingly.
content.html:
Currently gzserver --help does not return 0:

$ gzserver --help && echo this message should be echoed
gzserver -- Run the Gazebo server.

`gzserver` [options] <world_file>

Gazebo server runs simulation and handles commandline options, starts a Master, runs World update and sensor generation loops.

Options:
  -v [ --version ]              Output version information.
  --verbose                     Increase the messages written to the terminal.
  -h [ --help ]                 Produce this help message.
  -u [ --pause ]                Start the server in a paused state.
  -e [ --physics ] arg          Specify a physics engine 
                                (ode|bullet|dart|simbody).
  -p [ --play ] arg             Play a log file.
  -r [ --record ]               Record state data.
  --record_encoding arg (=zlib) Compression encoding format for log data 
                                (zlib|bz2|txt).
  --record_path arg             Absolute path in which to store state data
  --seed arg                    Start with a given random number seed.
  --iters arg                   Number of iterations to simulate.
  --minimal_comms               Reduce the TCP/IP traffic output by gzserver
  -s [ --server-plugin ] arg    Load a plugin.

This happens because Server::ParseArgs returns bool. server_main.cc uses the return value of Server::ParseArgs to determine if a server should be started.

Instead, I think Server::ParseArgs could return int, with a positive value indicating that a server should be started, and otherwise just pass along the returned value:

diff -r 4dc9b5b7ef30 gazebo/server_main.cc
--- a/gazebo/server_main.cc Fri Mar 20 17:48:04 2015 -0700
+++ b/gazebo/server_main.cc Mon Mar 23 17:53:15 2015 -0700
@@ -34,8 +34,11 @@
     gazebo::util::LogRecord::Instance()->Init("gzserver");

     server = new gazebo::Server();
-    if (!server->ParseArgs(argc, argv))
-      return -1;
+    {
+      int parse = server->ParseArgs(argc, argv);
+      if (parse <= 0)
+        return parse;
+    }

     server->Run();
     server->Fini();

Then the return codes in ParseArgs should be changed accordingly.

values.title: PID max and min command fails to limit when set to 0 (zero)

content.html:
This logic here precludes max or min command limits to be zero. I.e. if either cmdMax or cmdMin is 0, the controller does not limit the effort at all.

We should remove the check against zeros:

  if (this->cmd > this->cmdMax)
    this->cmd = this->cmdMax;
  if (this->cmd < this->cmdMin)
    this->cmd = this->cmdMin;

values.title: Need a robust way to differentiate link visuals from GUI visuals

content.html:
Model visuals contain several children, some are link visuals, others are GUI tools such as the manipulation tools (rendering::SelectionObj).

At times, having a model visual, we want to get only its link visuals. The way this is being done on gui::GLWidget for example, is to check visibility flags:

        // Find out if there's only one link in the model
        uint32_t flags = modelVis->GetChild(i)->GetVisibilityFlags();
        if ((flags != GZ_VISIBILITY_ALL) && (flags & GZ_VISIBILITY_GUI))
        {
          // not link
          continue;
        }

However, while implementing gui::ApplyForceDialog, I observed that this check works sometimes but fails other times. So for now, the dialog will be using a hack to explicitly ignore a visual whose name contains _GL_MANIP_ (SelectionObj) and consider everything else to be a link, which is not ideal.

values.title: Apply changes to physics parameters to GUI instantaneously

content.raw:
As Jose pointed out during the review of [PR 1557](#!/osrf/gazebo/pull-request/1557), changes to the physics engine don't get reflected in the GUI until the views representing the parameters get refreshed.

You can test this by running Gazebo and opening the "Physics" menu under the World tab in the left-hand menu, and in a terminal, typing

`gz physics --iters 100`

The "iterations" field will remain at 50 (or whatever value it was last set to) until you close and reopen the Physics menu.
content.html:
As Jose pointed out during the review of PR 1557, changes to the physics engine don't get reflected in the GUI until the views representing the parameters get refreshed.

You can test this by running Gazebo and opening the "Physics" menu under the World tab in the left-hand menu, and in a terminal, typing

gz physics --iters 100

values.title: ServerFixture definitions are not being installed

content.raw:
Gazebo is installing the `ServerFixture.hh` header with all the declarations but it is not providing the binary with the definitions nor the source code which can be used to compile the definitions.

This probably comes from the fact that in the good old times, ServerFixture.hh contained both definitions/declarations but now is split into different files.
content.html:
Gazebo is installing the ServerFixture.hh header with all the declarations but it is not providing the binary with the definitions nor the source code which can be used to compile the definitions.

This probably comes from the fact that in the good old times, ServerFixture.hh contained both definitions/declarations but now is split into different files.

values.title: Gazebo (gzclient) causes high CPU with an empty world

content.raw:
Running `gazebo` immediately causes nearly 100% CPU usage, even though I have no models loaded and have the simulation paused.

Running `top` shows, on average, that the CPU usage breaks down like:

    80% /usr/bin/gnome-shell
    60% gzclient
    20% Xorg
    10% gzserver

Obviously, the big offender is gnome-shell, but as soon as I quit gazebo, gnome-shell CPU usage drops to 3%.

My system is a dual-core Macbook Pro running:

    Ubuntu 12.04
    OpenGL 3.3.0 (NVIDIA 331.113 driver)
    Gazebo 4.1.1 (installed from the "Step-by-step" instructions at http://gazebosim.org/tutorials?tut=install_ubuntu&cat=installation)

Another odd thing I've noticed, is if I set "shadows" to "false" under World->Scene, then CPU usage immediately drops, although is still a bit high. The break down is roughly:

    20% gnome-shell
    20% gzclient
    10% gzserver

However, the if I click away and then back to World->Scene, the "shadow" value is reset to "true".

This seems related to my graphics driver. If I install gazebo on another 12.04 machine, but running OpenGL 3.0 (Mesa 10.1.3), gazebo runs fine with almost no CPU usage.

Running gazebo immediately causes nearly 100% CPU usage, even though I have no models loaded and have the simulation paused.

Running top shows, on average, that the CPU usage breaks down like:

80% /usr/bin/gnome-shell
60% gzclient
20% Xorg
10% gzserver

Obviously, the big offender is gnome-shell, but as soon as I quit gazebo, gnome-shell CPU usage drops to 3%.

My system is a dual-core Macbook Pro running:

Ubuntu 12.04
OpenGL 3.3.0 (NVIDIA 331.113 driver)
Gazebo 4.1.1 (installed from the "Step-by-step" instructions at http://gazebosim.org/tutorials?tut=install_ubuntu&cat=installation)

values.title: Memory leak camera

content.raw:
When running a camera in my world, the gzclient leaks around 3MB/s of memory. This is about the same bandwith as the raw_image topic uses when I connect an image_view to it. I think the render texture is not properly deleted.

This only occurs when using software rendering (On a VMware VM with HW acceleration turned off). It does not occur when I run Ubuntu native on a machine.

Both machines run Ubuntu 14.04 Trusty with the exact same packages. The VM has VMware tools installed and the native machine runs the nouveau driver.

The memory occurs both in the gzclient(when visualizing the camera) and in gzserver (when connecting via ROS or when viewing the topic via the gzclient).

values.title: Selection messages published recursively

content.raw:
1. Insert a few models in the scene

2. Start echoing selection messages on a terminal `gz topic -e /gazebo/default/selection`

3. With the mouse, click on the models in a random order quickly. It may take a while, but eventually you'll see the models getting selected by themselves, and the terminal will display a ton of selection messages.

I commented out `GLWidget`'s selection subscriber and was able to stop this from happening.

This sometimes causes a crash, but it seems to happen less often and I haven't got a backtrace yet.

values.title: It isn't possible to filter mouse events in system plugins

content.html:
Related question: http://answers.gazebosim.org/question/8500/how-to-return-the-controlling-to-default-event/

I wrote a simple system plugin to filter mouse events and confirmed what is described in the question above: the filter doesn't work if you give it a name other than glwidget and it works if you call it glwidget but then GLWidget's filter doesn't work.

#include <gazebo/gui/MouseEventHandler.hh>
#include <gazebo/gazebo.hh>

namespace gazebo
{
  class ExampleMousePlugin : public SystemPlugin
  {
    public: void Load(int /*_argc*/, char ** /*_argv*/)
    {
      gazebo::gui::MouseEventHandler::Instance()->AddReleaseFilter(
          "glwidget_or_not",
          boost::bind(&ExampleMousePlugin::OnMouseRelease, this, _1));
    }

    private: bool OnMouseRelease(const common::MouseEvent &_event)
    {
      std::cout << "release" << std::endl;
    }
  };
  GZ_REGISTER_SYSTEM_PLUGIN(ExampleMousePlugin)
}

I checked that the filter works as expected for GUI plugins though.

I guess the issue is related to the order in which the system plugin is loaded with respect to GLWidget. Its filter might be added before, so if:

  • name != "glwidget": GLWidget handles the event and it never reaches the plugin

  • name == "glwidget": Once GLWidget's event is loaded, the name already exists so it is just ignored...?

values.title: UNIT_SaveDialog_TEST fails on osx

content.raw:
The test passes on Linux but [fails on osx](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-default-devel-homebrew-amd64-2/19/testReport/junit/(root)/SaveDialog_TEST/SaveLocation/). I added some debugging print statements in cb25b0a (branch `save_dialog_test_osx`) to see what didn't match:
~~~
folderName:         model_name
expectedFolderName: model_name
actualSaveLocation:   /Users/model_name
expectedSaveLocation: /Users/scpeters/model_name
FAIL!  : SaveDialog_TEST::SaveLocation() 'actualSaveLocation == expectedSaveLocation' returned FALSE. ()
   Loc: [/Users/scpeters/ws/gazebo6/src/gazebo/gazebo/gui/SaveDialog_TEST.cc(80)]
~~~

It seems that [QDir::homePath().toStdString()](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/32287918490425e4f9fd5a06fbca3ade3e95f55d/gazebo/gui/SaveDialog_TEST.cc#cl-71) is returning `/Users` instead of `/Users/username`.
content.html:
The test passes on Linux but fails on osx. I added some debugging print statements in cb25b0a (branch save_dialog_test_osx) to see what didn't match:

folderName:         model_name
expectedFolderName: model_name
actualSaveLocation:   /Users/model_name
expectedSaveLocation: /Users/scpeters/model_name
FAIL!  : SaveDialog_TEST::SaveLocation() 'actualSaveLocation == expectedSaveLocation' returned FALSE. ()
   Loc: [/Users/scpeters/ws/gazebo6/src/gazebo/gazebo/gui/SaveDialog_TEST.cc(80)]

It seems that QDir::homePath().toStdString() is returning /Users instead of /Users/username.

values.title: Inconsistent hotkeys for snapping to grid

content.raw:
Hotkeys to turn snapping on and off seem to be inconsistent.

Inserting an entity:

* Default: Snaps to multiples of 1m
* Hold `Shift`: Free movement

Translating an entity:

* Default: Free movement
* Hold `Ctrl`: Snap to multiples of 1m
content.html:
Hotkeys to turn snapping on and off seem to be inconsistent.

Inserting an entity:

  • Default: Snaps to multiples of 1m
  • Hold Shift: Free movement

Translating an entity:

  • Default: Free movement
  • Hold Ctrl: Snap to multiples of 1m

values.title: Build fails with Boost 1.58

content.raw: [Boost 1.58](http://www.boost.org/users/history/version_1_58_0.html) was released today on Arch Linux, and Gazebo 5.0.1's build fails with `boost::bind`-related errors (cf. attached build logs).
content.html: Boost 1.58 was released today on Arch Linux, and Gazebo 5.0.1's build fails with boost::bind-related errors (cf. attached build logs).

values.title: Support images in the documentation

content.raw:
It was brought up by @\_jrivero\_ on pull request #1613 that adding images to our documentation could be very helpful to our users and contributors.

Quoting Jose:

"We would need to use the doxygen [image command](http://www.stack.nl/~dimitri/doxygen/manual/commands.html#cmdimage), store the image probably inside doc/ and maybe adjust the IMAGE_PATH variable in doc/gazebo.in."
content.html:
It was brought up by @_jrivero_ on pull request #1613 that adding images to our documentation could be very helpful to our users and contributors.

Quoting Jose:

"We would need to use the doxygen image command, store the image probably inside doc/ and maybe adjust the IMAGE_PATH variable in doc/gazebo.in."

values.title: Model editor: delete link collision and visual

content.raw: In the model editor, you can delete a link's visual and collision element without fully deleting the link. Attached joints will remain, and saving and exiting will occasionally lead to a crash. Otherwise, the created model will have an invisible link with neither a visual nor a collision shape. It will have a bounding box, however, and a name in the right hand menu.
content.html: In the model editor, you can delete a link's visual and collision element without fully deleting the link. Attached joints will remain, and saving and exiting will occasionally lead to a crash. Otherwise, the created model will have an invisible link with neither a visual nor a collision shape. It will have a bounding box, however, and a name in the right hand menu.

values.title: Add the ability to read and write the camera pose by coordinates from the GUI

content.raw: It would be useful if camera's current x/y/z/r/p/y pose values were visible in the left-hand panel, with the option to set them as you would any other Gazebo variable. Currently, if you want to find the exact camera pose, you have to manually position the camera with the mouse, save the world to a file, and then scrap the coordinates from the file.
content.html: It would be useful if camera's current x/y/z/r/p/y pose values were visible in the left-hand panel, with the option to set them as you would any other Gazebo variable. Currently, if you want to find the exact camera pose, you have to manually position the camera with the mouse, save the world to a file, and then scrap the coordinates from the file.

values.title: Circular dependency when reviewing linking on physics

content.raw:
Currently, `gazebo_physics` library needs to link against `gazebo_physics_${engine}` since they are using the `GZ_REGISTER_PHYSICS_ENGINE` macro which generate the definition for previous declarations of `Register${engine}()` functions.

So, we need to link `gazebo_physics` against the other `gazebo_physics_${engine}` libraries. There is currently no linking declared in `gazebo_physics_${engine}` against `gazebo_physics` although it is really using symbols from it.
content.html:
Currently, gazebo_physics library needs to link against gazebo_physics_${engine} since they are using the GZ_REGISTER_PHYSICS_ENGINE macro which generate the definition for previous declarations of Register${engine}() functions.

So, we need to link gazebo_physics against the other gazebo_physics_${engine} libraries. There is currently no linking declared in gazebo_physics_${engine} against gazebo_physics although it is really using symbols from it.

values.title: Scoped names specified in sdf don't work when there are mulitple instances of a model

content.raw:
Take joint for example, when there is one model the following works:

~~~
<model name="my_model">
  <link name="link1">...</link>
  <link name="link2">...</link>
  <joint name="joint1" type="revolute">
    <parent>my_model::link1</parent>
    <child>my_model::link2</child>
  </joint>
</model>
~~~

when when you insert another instance of the same model, the model name gets a number appended to it. In the case above, `my_model` becomes `my_model_0`. This invalidates all references to links and joints in this model if using scoped names.

Same applies to references specified inside `<plugin>`
content.html:
Take joint for example, when there is one model the following works:

<model name="my_model">
  <link name="link1">...</link>
  <link name="link2">...</link>
  <joint name="joint1" type="revolute">
    <parent>my_model::link1</parent>
    <child>my_model::link2</child>
  </joint>
</model>

when when you insert another instance of the same model, the model name gets a number appended to it. In the case above, my_model becomes my_model_0. This invalidates all references to links and joints in this model if using scoped names.

Same applies to references specified inside <plugin>

values.title: HAPTIX environment setup tutorial nvidia drivers install incorrect

content.raw:
From http://gazebosim.org/tutorials?tut=haptix_unboxing&cat=haptix#Environmentoverview

You will need to install nvidia drivers from a PPA. Type the following into the terminal:

deb http://ppa.launchpad.net/xorg-edgers/ppa/ubuntu trusty main 
deb-src http://ppa.launchpad.net/xorg-edgers/ppa/ubuntu trusty main 

Then:

sudo apt-get install nvidia-<version number>

You may need to restart your computer for the new drivers to take effect.

**Instead, the following was required:**
sudo add-apt-repository -y ppa:xorg-edgers/ppa
sudo apt-get update
sudo apt-get install nvidia-<version number>
content.html:
From http://gazebosim.org/tutorials?tut=haptix_unboxing&cat=haptix#Environmentoverview

You will need to install nvidia drivers from a PPA. Type the following into the terminal:

deb http://ppa.launchpad.net/xorg-edgers/ppa/ubuntu trusty main deb-src http://ppa.launchpad.net/xorg-edgers/ppa/ubuntu trusty main

Then:

sudo apt-get install nvidia-<version number>

You may need to restart your computer for the new drivers to take effect.

Instead, the following was required: sudo add-apt-repository -y ppa:xorg-edgers/ppa sudo apt-get update sudo apt-get install nvidia-<version number>
